description: From Middle English unkind; equivalent to un- +‎ kind.

adjectives.description: unkind (comparative unkinder or more unkind, superlative unkindest or most unkind)

entries.meaning: Lacking kindness, sympathy, benevolence, gratitude, or similar; cruel, harsh or unjust; ungrateful. [from mid-14th c.]
examples: Despite the bursitis, Dewey got in a good round of golf, though his cautious game inspired a reporter to make one of the week′s unkindest remarks: “He plays golf like he plays politics — straight down the middle, and short.”

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Not kind; contrary to nature or type; unnatural. [from 13th c.]
examples: […]  A Feauer is an vnkinde heate, that commeth out of the heart, and passeth into all the members of the bodye, and grieueth the working of the bodye.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Having no race or kindred; childless.
